If you‚Äôre reading this, you‚Äôre probably like me‚Äîspending most of your days in your office, in front of a computer. You probably have fifteen tabs open: one for email, one for Slack, one for Google Docs, and on, and on‚Ä¶ But have you ever thought about where these ‚Äúwork tools‚Äù came from? Or why there are so many of them? To answer these questions, and to explain why we created Notion, we have to travel back in time. As people flooded to factories during the Industrial Revolution, many tools were invented to ease the management overload. Typewriters replaced illegible handwriting. File cabinets stored more information than any clerk could remember (and also won the gold medal at the 1893 Chicago World‚Äôs Fair!) Tools like these paved the way for offices as we know them today. Fast forward to the 1950s, when computers came into the workplace. At first, they were lifeless, room-sized monsters that operated on paper and punch cards. They were used solely for number-crunching. Then something magical happened in the 1970s! A generation of pioneers saw the computer as something far beyond a number-crunching machine. They dreamt a future where computers could amplify imagination (Alan Kay), augment intellect (Doug Engelbart), and expand our thoughts far beyond text on paper (Ted Nelson). A tool unlike anything we have seen before. Play Uh-oh! It looks like your ad blocker is preventing the video from playing. Please watch it on YouTube But things didn‚Äôt turn out that way. As the legend goes, when Steve Jobs ‚Äúborrowed‚Äù the ideas behind personal computing from Xerox PARC, many subtle, but crucial, differences were lost. Hit play and listen to the man himself. And that‚Äôs where we are today. Google Docs made typewriters multiplayer. Dropbox brought file cabinets to the cloud. But conceptually, they evolved little beyond their Industrial Revolution ancestors. We duct-tape everything together with emails, copy/paste, and countless open tabs. That‚Äôs where Notion comes in. We want to break away from today‚Äôs tools‚Äîand bring back some of the ideas of those early pioneers. As a first step, we are blending much of your workflow into an all-in-one workspace . Want a task list? A product roadmap? A design repository? They are now all in one place. You can even customize your own workspace from dozens of building blocks. Solve your problems your way, bounded only by your imagination. Hopefully you‚Äôve gotten a good sense of why we started Notion. Challenging the status quo is not an easy task. Check out the product! Write in! We need early adopters like you to start a movement. See you soon! ‚Äú The best way to predict the future is to invent it. ‚Äù Alan Kay, computing pioneer Join us Notion is based in beautiful downtown San Francisco, with offices around the world. We are a diverse group of people interested in computing, history, art, alternative programming languages, and skateboarding. Interested in joining us?
